Situation1: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A heat advisory is issued for the day and an elderly neighbor on the floor lives alone.
Story: The sun blazed overhead as I scanned the pool, my whistle ready. As a lifeguard, I was expected to enforce every safety rule, no exceptions. That’s when I spotted a group of teenagers laughing and diving right under the bold, red “NO DIVING” sign. My training screamed at me to intervene immediately—one wrong move and someone could be seriously hurt. But as a citizen, I couldn’t ignore the heat advisory blaring from my phone. My elderly neighbor, Mrs. Kim, lived alone on the floor above. She rarely turned on her air conditioning, and I worried about her in this oppressive heat. I felt the weight of both roles pressing down on me: the pool needed my vigilance, but Mrs. Kim might need my help. My mind raced, torn between the urgent demands of my job and my responsibility to my community. I gripped the whistle tighter, heart pounding, caught in the impossible space between duty and compassion, knowing I had to choose.
